Subjective: Right leg pain radiating from back to foot, posterior thigh and lateral lower leg. Onset 1.5 weeks ago, worsening. Constant pain, worse with movement. Unable to sleep due to pain. Pain not relieved by max dose paracetamol/ibuprofen. Started when lifting heavy objects at work. Temporarily stopped working. Reports duller sensation on right lateral lower leg. Reports some tingling in same area. No weakness in leg. No numbness/altered sensation in perianal/riding breeches area. No bowel/bladder incontinence. Request: Wants to get rid of pain.
Objective: Pain on ambulation to exam table. No gross abnormalities noted on visual inspection of back/legs. Palpation of back: no vertebral tenderness. Right leg lift elicits pain. Left leg lift: no pain. Strength testing: bilateral leg strength equal, but pain limits movement on right. Sensation: duller on right lateral lower leg. Reflexes: normal bilaterally. No saddle anesthesia. No bowel/bladder dysfunction.
Assessment: Lumbar disc herniation with radiculopathy, right leg. Nerve pain. No red flags for cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: 1. Pain management: Start pregabalin, titrate dose slowly due to side effects. Advised not to drive while starting/titrating dose or if experiencing side effects. Goal: improve sleep and pain control. 2. Physiotherapy referral for exercises to improve back flexibility and reduce disc compression. 3. Conservative management: pain relief and physiotherapy preferred over immediate surgery/imaging. 4. Safety netting: Contact GP/out-of-hours if worsening symptoms, loss of sensation in riding breeches area, new bowel/bladder dysfunction, or significant leg weakness. 5. Follow-up: Telephone appointment in 1 week to assess pain management effectiveness.
